title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: J&J to Spin Off Consumer Business; Ex-MoviePass CEO Pitches Reboot; Antitrust Plaintiffs Press Drugmaker
text:
J&J to split off consumer division. Johnson & Johnson plans to break up into two companies, splitting off the $15 billion-a-year division that sells Band-Aid bandages, Tylenol medicines and Johnson's Baby powder in a dramatic shift indicating just how much healthcare has changed since the company helped pioneer the industry. The consumer division has faced lawsuits alleging talc-containing Johnson's Baby powder caused cancer or mesothelioma, which J&J denies, but it has shifted those talc claims into bankruptcy court to try to drive a settlement.

Ex-MoviePass CEO will test out a possible sequel. The co-founder and former chief of MoviePass Inc. is getting ready to test whether the popular—though failed—theater subscription service can return for a second act with a new business model. He said he would test a revised business plan during the holiday season.

Plaintiffs want Teligent price-fixing lawsuit to continue despite bankruptcy. Drug buyers are seeking court permission to continue a price-fixing lawsuit against Teligent Inc. despite the halt on litigation that kicked in when the drugmaker filed for bankruptcy.

Funds

SEC considering new rules on private-fund fees, conflicts. Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Gary Gensler said he has asked agency staff for proposals to reform a slate of troublesome practices by private-equity and hedge-fund managers, including unclear performance metrics and opacity in fees and expenses.

HPS targets $9.5 billion for fifth junior-debt fund. Private markets investment firm HPS Investment Partners is pitching a new junior debt fund to investors, weeks after collecting $11.7 billion for a separate fund focused on specialty loans.

Bankruptcy

Travel firm CWT files prepack. Family-owned business travel agency CWT filed a prepackaged bankruptcy case to hand control to creditors. The firm's chapter 11 strategy will cut roughly half of a $1.6 billion debt load while providing $350 million in fresh equity capital through a backstopped rights offering, according to court papers filed in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Houston.

Supermajorities of lenders, bondholders and CWT's equity owners all support the prepackaged deal. The firm restructured its balance sheet outside of chapter 11 last year after the Covid-19 pandemic slammed the travel industry, but needs to do so again after a spike in infections in early 2021 caused passenger volumes to fall again, CEO Michelle McKinney Frymire said in a sworn declaration.

"The plan is overwhelmingly supported by all voting classes and all formal and informal objections are resolved," she said. — Andrew Scurria

In Other News

More than half of Black bankruptcy filers are steered toward Chapter 13 bankruptcy—twice the rate of White, Hispanic or Asian filers. That disparity is significant for Black filers who saw Chapter 13 issues exacerbated by the pandemic, which drove job losses, added unexpected medical bills, and a widened wealth and homeownership gap. (Bloomberg)

Law firm Edelson says financial records from the bankruptcy of famed plaintiffs lawyer Tom Girardi show that Girardi's estranged wife, reality television star Erika Girardi, received money misappropriated from victims of the Lion Air crash who were represented by her husband. (Reuters)

A longtime Chicago doctor faces potential criminal contempt charges after he allegedly brandished a handgun during a video-conferenced bankruptcy court hearing in the midst of a testy eviction dispute with his landlord. (Chicago Tribune)
